import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Plots in $\mathbb{R}^2$¶

Example plotting simple functions.¶

The sign function \begin{equation*} f(x)=\text{sign}(x) \end{equation*} can be approximated by the hyperbolic tangent function
\begin{equation*} f(x)=\tanh(kx) \end{equation*} for $k$ large enough.
The numpy library has implementations of all the above functions.

In [2]:
x=np.linspace(-5,5,200)  #generates 200 equally spaced points in  [-5, 5),  starting from value -5 not including 5
y1=np.sign(x);           #gets the corresponding value for those points based on the sign function

#plot the sign function based on the points generated above
f1, ax=plt.subplots()            
ax.plot(x,y1, color='black', linewidth=2)
ax.set_title("Approximations of the Sign function")
#plot the tanh function on the same plot, for 4 different k values
k=[0.5,1,2,10]
col=["red","brown","green", "blue"]
for i in range(4):
    yk=np.tanh(k[i]*x)
    ax.plot(x,yk,color=col[i], linewidth=2)
ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y")
#create a grid and a legend    
ax.grid()
ax.legend(("sign(x)", "tanh(x/2)", "tanh(x)", "tanh(2x)", "tanh(10x)"))
Out[2]:
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x24ec406e8c8>

Probability and Random Variables¶

Generating random values¶

One can use the random module of numpy to generate random numbers from different distributions.
Lets try a few different distributions.

  • Simulating the roll of a die : randomnly generate $n$ numbers from the {1,2,3,4,5,6} set, each equally likely to be picked.
    Use randint function in the random module of numpy, can be used to generate integer numbers from a uniform distribution.
    • Generate 10,000 random numbers. Count and plot the frequency of occurence for each value
In [3]:
n=10000
# 1
r=np.random.randint(1,7,size=n)
print("First 10 random values generated :", r[:10])

x=list(r);
values=[1,2,3,4,5,6]
frequency=[];
for v in values:
    frequency.append(x.count(v))

fig, ax1=plt.subplots();
ax1.bar(values, frequency)
ax1.set_ylabel('frequency')
ax1.set_xlabel('value')
ax1.set_title('Distribution of values for 10,000 rolls')

First 10 random values generated : [4 4 1 6 2 5 2 1 2 4]
Out[3]:
Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Distribution of values for 10,000 rolls')

  • Randomly generate numbers uniformly in the $\left[0,1\right]$ interval.
    Can use rand function in the random module of numpy.

  • Randomly generate numbers uniformly in the $\left[-5,5\right]$ interval.

    1. Generate numbers uniformly in $\left[0,1\right]$
    2. Scale the by 10 by multiplying by 10), so the numbers are distributed uniformly in $\left[0,10\right]$
    3. Shift by 5 by subtracting 5, so the numbers are distributed uniformly in $\left[-5,5\right]$
In [4]:

  • Randomly generate 10,000 values from a Gaussian (normal) distribution with mean $\mu$ and standard deviation $\sigma$.
    Using normal function in the random module of numpy.
    Density function of the Gaussian is the bell-shaped curve given by \begin{equation*} f(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi \sigma ^2}}e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2} \end{equation*}
  • Plot the empirical distribution

Note: scipy.stats library has a large amount of statistical functions and distributions implemented (https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/stats.html)

In [5]:
n=10000

mu=2
sigma=3
rn=np.random.normal(mu, sigma,n);

print(10, "gaussian random numbers with mean=",mu," and std=", sigma, ":")
print(rn[:10], "\n")

#get histograms - play around with the number of bins etc.
a1, b1=np.histogram(rn,50)
f1, ax2 = plt.subplots()

x=b1[1:];
dx=x[1]-x[0];
y=1./(np.sqrt(2.*np.pi)*sigma)*np.exp(-np.power((x - mu)/sigma, 2.)/2)
ax2.plot(x,y,color='red');
ax2.bar(x-dx/2,a1/n/dx);
ax2.set_title("Gaussian Distribution")
ax2.set_ylabel("density")
ax2.set_xlabel("value")
ax2.legend(['Theoretical','Empirical'])

NumPy Arrays¶

NumPy’s main data structure is the (multidimensional) array.

Note: here is a good resource for learning more about NumPy arrays (https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/machine-learning-with/9781491989371/ch01.html)

Vectors (1D arrays)¶

In [6]:
v=np.array(np.random.randint(1,100, size=10)) #generate a random array of size 10

a=v[3]   #the 4th element of v (element of index 3, counting starts at 0)
b=v[-1]  #the last element of v 
c=v[:4]  #the first 4 elements of v
d=v[2:]  #the last elements of v starting from index 2
e=v[1:5] #the elements of v with index 1,2,3,4
f=v[v>50] #the elements of v that are greater than 50

print("v :", v, "\n")

Operations¶

  1. operators +,-,* , /, ** (power) are defined as element by element operations
  2. Given two vectors \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} v & = & \left[ v_0,v_1, ...,v_n \right] \\ u & = & \left[ u_0,u_1, ...,u_n \right] \\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*} the dot product: $v\cdot u$ is defined \begin{equation*} v\cdot u=v_0u_0+v_1u_1+...+v_nu_n=\sum_{i=0}^{n}v_iu_i \end{equation*}
In [7]:
n=5
v=np.array(np.random.randint(1,100, size=n)) #generate a random array of size n
a=v*10    #the elements of v multiplied by 10
b=v-50   #the elements of v substracted 50
c=v**2   #the square of the elements of v 
d=np.sqrt(v) #the square root of the elements of v
e=-v #the negation of v
print("v :", v, "\n")
print(a,b,c,d,e, sep="\n")

u=np.array(np.linspace(0,16,n)) #array consisting of n points between 0 and 16 inclusive
print("\n\nu :", u, "\n")

f=v*u #element by element multiplication
print("f=u*v : ", f, "\n")
g=v+u #element by element addition
print("g=u+v : ", g, "\n")

h=np.dot(u,v)  #dot product of the array 
print("h= np.dot(u,v) : ", h, "\n")

#alternatives ways of doing the dot product
h1=u.dot(v)
h2=u @ v #python 3.5 and after only

print(h1,h2, sep="\n")

Linear functions in $\mathbb{R}^2$¶

Consider the function \begin{equation*} f(x_1,x_2)=w_0 + w_1x_1 + w_2x_2 \end{equation*}

What is the set of points $x_1,x_2$ where the function becomes 0? For $ w_2\neq 0 $ \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} 0=f(x_1,x_2)=w_0 + w_1x_1 + w_2x_2 & \implies & x_2=-\frac{1}{w_2}\left(w_0 + w_1x_1\right)\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

Let's generate a few random values for $w_i$ and plot the results. Without loss of generality $-1\leq w_i\leq 1$

In [11]:
x1=np.linspace(-5,5,200)

f3, ax3=plt.subplots();
col=["red","brown","green", "blue", "black"]

for i in range(5):
    w=np.random.rand(3)*2-1
    print(w)
    x2=-(w[0]+w[1]*x1)/w[2]
    ax3.plot(x1,x2, color=col[i], linewidth=2)
ax3.grid()
ax3.set_xlabel("$x_1$")
ax3.set_ylabel("$x_2$")
ax3.set_title("Drawing Random Lines on a Plane");

[ 0.76452516 -0.26482083 -0.2367013 ]
[0.31825275 0.39374472 0.73847403]
[-0.63540484 -0.37342094  0.27154717]
[-0.50068398 -0.9481619   0.08255818]
[-0.64448417  0.83016368  0.86549156]

As we can see, interpreted this way, any set of 3 weights $(w_0,w_1,w_2)$ defines a line in the plane. Indeed since we can always normalize by $w_2$, any two weights define a line on the plane.

Synthetic Linearly-Separable Data¶

Let us now generate a synthetic data set in $\mathbb{R}^2$ following these steps:

1-Randomly generate a line (i.e., generate $w_0,w_1,w_2$)

2-Randomly generate $N$ data points as above

3-For each point $(x_2,x_1)$, calculate \begin{equation*} f(x_1,x_2)= w_0+w_1x_1+w_2x_2 \end{equation*} If $f(x_1,x_2)>0$, label the point $+1$, otherwise label $-1$

In [13]:
N=200
w=np.random.rand(3)*2-1
datax=np.random.rand(N,2)*10-5
#print(w)
#print(datax)

z=-(w[0]+w[1]*datax[:,0])/w[2]
datay=((w[0]+w[1]*datax[:,0]+w[2]*datax[:,1])>0)*2-1
#print(datay)
f5, ax5=plt.subplots()
ax5.plot(datax[datay>0,0],datax[datay>0,1], 'r+')
ax5.plot(datax[datay<0,0],datax[datay<0,1], 'bo')
ax5.plot(datax[:,0],z,'k')
ax5.set_xlabel("$x_1$")
ax5.set_ylabel("$x_2$")
ax5.set_title("Linearly Separable Points in  $\mathbb{R}^2$");
ax5.axis([-5.5,5.5,-5.5,5.5])
Out[13]:
[-5.5, 5.5, -5.5, 5.5]

3D Plots and Linear functions in $\mathbb{R}^3$¶

Consider \begin{equation*} f(x_1,x_2,x_3)=w_0 + w_1x_1 + w_2x_2 +w_3x_3 \end{equation*} Let's generate a few random values for $w_i$ and plot the results. Wlog $-1\leq w_i\leq 1$

y = np.linspace(-5, 5, 40)
X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, y)

w=np.random.rand(4)*2-1
Z = (w[0]+w[1]*X+w[2]*Y)/w[3]
ax.plot_surface(X, Y, Z)
ax.set_title('A Separating Plane');
ax.set_xlabel('x')

Synthetic Data in $\mathbb{R}^3$¶

Let us now generate a synthetic data set in $\mathbb{R}^3$ following these steps: 1-Randomly generate a plane (i.e., generate $w_0,w_1,w_2, w_3$)

2-Randomly generate $N$ data points as above

3-For each point $(x_1,x_2,x_3)$, calculate \begin{equation*} f(x_1,x_2,x_3)= w_0+w_1x_1+w_2x_2+w_3x_3 \end{equation*} If $f(x_1,x_2,x_3)>0$, label the point $+1$, otherwise label $-1$

datax=np.random.rand(N,3)*10-5

#plt.figure()

ax3.plot_surface(X,Y,Z)

Linear classification using a synthetic data set¶

  • Given the input $x=(x_1, x_2, \ldots , x_n)\in \mathbb{R}^n$ and
  • the output $y \in \left\{-1, +1\right\}$,
  • the goal is to find a function $g : \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \left\{-1, +1\right\}$, so that $g(x)$ predicts y correctly most of the time.

One approach would be to take a weighted sum of the coordinates $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$, and to check if the average is above a certain threshold $\theta$. If it is above the threshold, it predicts the label +1, otherwise it predicts the label -1.
i.e.,

\begin{equation*} g(x) = \left\{ \begin{matrix} -1 & \text{if}\quad w_1x_1+w_2x_2+\ldots +w_nx_n < \theta \\ +1 & \text{if}\quad w_1x_1+w_2x_2+\ldots +w_nx_n \geq \theta \\ \end{matrix} \right. \end{equation*}

This is called a linear classifier.

Lets do a bit of notation change by letting $w_0=-\theta$
Then \begin{equation*} w_1x_1+w_2x_2+\ldots +w_nx_n < \theta \end{equation*} becomes \begin{equation*} w_0 + w_1x_1+w_2x_2+\ldots +w_nx_n < 0 \end{equation*}

and $g(x)$ can be rewritten as

\begin{equation*} g(x)=\text{sign}\left(w_0 + w_1x_1+w_2x_2+\ldots +w_nx_n\right) \end{equation*}

Vector Notation

  • Augment the input $x$, so that it has a zero-th coordinate $x_0$ which is always set to 1.
    i.e., $x=\left(x_0, x_1, x_2, \ldots , x_n\right)$, where $x_0=1$.
  • Let $w=\left(w_0,w_1,\ldots, w_n\right) $, then
    \begin{equation*} g(x)=\text{sign}\left(x\cdot w\right) \end{equation*}

Task of learning for linear classifiers : Find $w$ so that $g$ is a good predictor of y given different inputs x.

In [21]:
import numpy as np

  • vector $x_2$ will contain the values of the second coordinate of the data points
  • vector $y$ will contain the labels for each of the data points

Classification Error¶

Given a linear classifier (i.e., given the weights that define the line), calculate the classification error.

  1. First, lets generate a random classifier for the data above (i.e, generate $w=(w_0,w_1,w_2)$)
  2. Plot the classifier
  3. Calculate the classification error

To calculate the error, for each point $(x_1,x_2,y)$ :

  • Calculate
\begin{equation*} h(x_1,x_2)=\text{sign}(w_0+w_1x_1+w_2x_2) \end{equation*}
  • \begin{equation*} error = \left\{ \begin{matrix} 1 & \text{if}\quad h(x_1,x_2)\neq y \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \\ \end{matrix} \right. \end{equation*}


Sum over all the points and divide by $N$ to get the error

In [23]:
#1 generating a random classifier
w=np.random.rand(3)*2-1

#plotting the points
fig1, ax1=plt.subplots()
ax1.plot(x1[y>0],x2[y>0],'r+')
ax1.plot(x1[y<0],x2[y<0],'bo')
ax1.set_xlabel("$x_1$")
ax1.set_ylabel("$x_2$")
ax1.axis([-5.1,5.1,-5.1,5.1])

#2 plotting the classifier
z=-(w[0]+w[1]*x1)/w[2]
ax1.plot(x1,z, color='black', linewidth=2)


#3 calculating the error
h=np.sign(w[0]+w[1]*x1+w[2]*x2)
ey=(h!=y)
error=100*sum(ey)/N
print("Error: ", error, "%")

Error:  35.0 %

Random Classifiers¶

Given a performance bound (say error smaller than $\epsilon$), how many tries would it take to achieve said performance by generating random linear classifiers?

Using matrix notation¶

Let's try do do the same thing using matrix notation.

The data is given by $D$, an $N \times 3$ array.
The first $2$ columns is the input and the last column is the output.
Let's create an $N\times 3$ array $X$ for the input (the first column is all ones).

$X$ will look like
1 x1 x2 1 2.5055315 3.1243139 1 -3.8724829 -4.55520539 1 -1.41786264 -3.9505169 1 -4.77589568 3.61261014 1 0.54364724 -3.27139691 ...

i.e, \begin{equation*} X= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2.5055315 & 3.1243139 \\ 1 & -3.8724829 & -4.55520539 \\ 1 & -1.41786264 & -3.9505169 \\ 1 & -4.77589568 & 3.61261014 \\ 1 & 0.54364724 & -3.27139691 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

Then calculating $ℎ(𝑥_1,𝑥_2)=\text{sign}\left(𝑤_0+𝑤_1𝑥_1+𝑤_2𝑥_2\right)$ for all the points can be done in one shot by calculating the dot product of $X$ and $w$, so \begin{equation*} h(x)=\text{sign}\left(Xw\right) \end{equation*}

In [26]:
X=np.ones((N,3))
X[:, 1:3]=D[:, 0:2]
y=D[:,2]
In [27]:

    ey=(h!=y)
    error=100*sum(ey)/N
    #print (i, "Error: ", error, "%" )
print ("Try #", i, "\tError: ", error, "%" )
print("Best Classifier Weights :", w)

Best Classifier Weights : [ 0.41437938 -0.1022863  -0.27595974]

Perceptron Learning Algorithm (PLA)¶

Construct $X$
1 x1 x2 1 2.5055315 3.1243139 1 -3.8724829 -4.55520539 1 -1.41786264 -3.9505169 1 -4.77589568 3.61261014 1 0.54364724 -3.27139691 ...

$y$ is the vector will all the point labels stacked.

Get the classifier weights using the following algorithm:

  1. Start with a random w
  2. classify points using the weights w (i.e, $\;\;h=sign(X \cdot w)$
  3. Pick a misclassified point (i.e, pick $k$ such that $h[k]\neq y[k]$. Lets call this point $(\tilde{x}, \tilde{y})$
  4. Update weights $w\leftarrow w+\tilde{y}\cdot \tilde{x}$
  5. Repeat 2-4 until no misclassified points.
In [29]:
def PLA(data):
    """ Given data, use PLA to find the separating hyper plane""" 
    [N, d]=np.shape(data)
    X=np.ones((N,d))
    X[:, 1:d]=data[:, 0:d-1]
    Y=data[:,d-1]
    w=np.random.rand(d)*2-1 #randomly initialize the weights
    i=0
    while 1:
        h=np.sign(X @ w).T
        ey=(h!=Y)  #missmatched points
        trainerr=sum(ey);  #number of missmatched
        if trainerr==0:
            break
        #pick a random missmatched
        if trainerr==1:
            k=0
        else:
            k=np.random.randint(0,trainerr-1) 
        xx=(X[ey,:])[k]
        yy=(Y[ey])[k]
        #update weights
        w=w+yy*xx;
        #print("Epoch: ", i, "Error :", trainerr/N*100, "%")
        i=i+1;
    print ("Epoch: ", i, "Error: ", trainerr/N*100, "%")
    return w
In [30]:

In [31]:
def PLA_Illustration(data, steps=None):
    """ Given data, use PLA to find the separating hyper plane""" 
    [N, d]=np.shape(data)
    x1=data[:,0]
    x2=data[:,1]
    y=data[:,2]
    if steps is None:
        mm=10
    else:
        mm=steps
    fig2, ax2=plt.subplots(1,mm, figsize=(8*mm,6))
 

    
    X=np.ones((N,3))
    X[:, 1:3]=data[:, 0:2]
    Y=data[:,2]
    w=np.random.rand(3)*2-1 #randomly initialize the weights
    


    i=0
    while 1:
        if (i>=mm):
            break;
 
        
        h=np.sign(X @ w).T
        ey=(h!=Y)  #missmatched points
        trainerr=sum(ey);  #number of missmatched
        if trainerr==0:
            break
        #pick a random missmatched
        if trainerr==1:
            k=0
        else:
            k=np.random.randint(0,trainerr-1) 
        xx=(X[ey,:])[k]
        yy=(Y[ey])[k]
        #update weights
        z=-(w[0]+w[1]*x1)/w[2]   
        ax2[i].plot(xx[1],xx[2],'y*', markersize=14)
        ax2[i].plot(x1[y>0],x2[y>0],'r+')
        ax2[i].plot(x1[y<0],x2[y<0],'bo')
        ax2[i].plot(x1,z, color='black', linewidth=2)
        ax2[i].arrow(0,0,w[1],w[2], head_width=0.5, color='green', length_includes_head=True)
        ax2[i].set_xlabel("$x_1$")
        ax2[i].set_ylabel("$x_2$")
        ax2[i].axis([-5.1,5.1,-5.1,5.1])
        ax2[i].set_title("Error = "+str(int(trainerr)))
        w=w+yy*xx;
        #print("Epoch: ", i, "Error :", trainerr/N*100, "%")
        
        z=-(w[0]+w[1]*x1)/w[2]
        ax2[i].plot(x1,z, color='magenta', linewidth=2)
        ax2[i].arrow(0,0,w[1],w[2], head_width=0.5, color='red', length_includes_head=True)
        ax2[i].arrow(0,0,xx[1],xx[2], head_width=0.5, color='cyan', length_includes_head=True)
        i=i+1;
    print ("Epoch: ", i, "Error: ", trainerr/N*100, "%")
    return w

Linear Regression Classifier¶

Construct $X$
1 x1 x2 1 2.5055315 3.1243139 1 -3.8724829 -4.55520539 1 -1.41786264 -3.9505169 1 -4.77589568 3.61261014 1 0.54364724 -3.27139691 ...

i.e, \begin{equation*} X= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2.5055315 & 3.1243139 \\ 1 & -3.8724829 & -4.55520539 \\ 1 & -1.41786264 & -3.9505169 \\ 1 & -4.77589568 & 3.61261014 \\ 1 & 0.54364724 & -3.27139691 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

$y$ is the vector will all the point labels stacked.

\begin{equation*} y= \begin{bmatrix} +1\\ +1\\ -1\\ +1 \\ -1 \\ \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

Question: Are there linear combinations of the data that predict the output?

i.e., are there weights $w_0, w_1, w_2$, such that $y= w_0+ w_1x_1+w_2x_2$ for all the points? Basically what we want is

\begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} w_0 & + & 2.50553150 \cdot w_1 & + & 3.12431390 \cdot w_2 & = & +1 \\ w_0 & + & -3.87248290 \cdot w_1 & + & -4.55520539 \cdot w_2 & = & +1 \\ w_0 & + & -1.41786264 \cdot w_1 & + & -3.95051690 \cdot w_2 & = & -1 \\ w_0 & + & -4.77589568 \cdot w_1 & + & 3.61261014 \cdot w_2 & = & +1 \\ w_0 & + & 0.54364724 \cdot w_1 & + & -3.27139691 \cdot w_2 & = & -1 \\ &&&\vdots&&&\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

In matrix notation this would be

\begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2.50553150 & 3.12431390 \\ 1 & -3.87248290 & -4.55520539 \\ 1 & -1.41786264 & -3.95051690 \\ 1 & -4.77589568 & 3.61261014 \\ 1 & 0.54364724 & -3.2713969 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} w_0 \\ w_1 \\ w_2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} +1 \\ +1 \\ -1 \\ +1 \\ -1 \\ \vdots\\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

or \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} X & w &= &y\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

Such equation generally will not have a solution, since $X$ is a tall matrix (i.e., a lot more rows than columns). The best one can do is pick approximate solutions. One such solution would be the one that maximizes the mean squared error. This is the linear regression solution found using the formula

\begin{equation*} w=(X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty \end{equation*}

Alternatively get $w$ by getting the least square solution of matrix equation $Xw=y$ by calling the numpy.linalg.lstsq function.

In [33]:
[N, d]=np.shape(D)
X=np.ones((N,d))
X[:, 1:d]=D[:, 0:d-1]
y=D[:,d-1]
sol=np.linalg.lstsq(X,y,rcond=None)
w_lr=sol[0]

#w_lr=(np.linalg.inv(X.T @ X) @ X.T) @ Y

xp=np.linspace(-5,5,100)
z=-(w_lr[0]+w_lr[1]*xp)/w_lr[2]

x1=D[:,0]
x2=D[:,1]
y=D[:,2]

fig3, ax3=plt.subplots()
ax3.plot(x1[y>0],x2[y>0],'r+')
ax3.plot(x1[y<0],x2[y<0],'bo')
ax3.plot(xp,z, color='black', linewidth=2)
ax3.set_xlabel("$x_1$")
ax3.set_ylabel("$x_2$")
ax3.axis([-5.1,5.1,-5.1,5.1])

print('Linear Regression Classifier Weights', w_lr)

Nonlinear Transformations and Linear Regression¶

Let's start by looking some inputs in $\mathbb{R}$, i.e., one dimensional data.

Given the data points above, fit the best line to the data : Linear Regression
What we are doing is that best function of the form \begin{equation*} h(x)=w_0+w_1x \end{equation*} that fits the data

  • Form the matrix X
    \begin{equation*} X= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -0.97475132 \\ 1 & -0.51516923 \\ 1 & 1.12807075 \\ \vdots & \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

  • Reminder that y \begin{equation*} y= \begin{bmatrix} 0.02398749 \\ 0.12831898 \\ 0.42007667 \\ \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

  • Solve for $w$ \begin{equation*} Xw=y \end{equation*}

What if we wanted to fit the best quadratic function? Than we need to find the best function of the form \begin{equation*} h(x)=w_0+w_1x+w_2x^2 \end{equation*} that fits the data.
I.e., we approximate $y$ by:

Find $w_0, w_1, w_2$ so that \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} w_0 &+& −0.97475132\cdot w_1&+& (−0.97475132)^2 \cdot w_2 & = & 0.02398749 \\ w_0 &+& −0.51516923\cdot w_1&+& (−0.51516923)^2 \cdot w_2 & = & 0.12831898 \\ w_0 &+& 1.12807075\cdot w_1&+& (1.12807075)^2 \cdot w_2 & = & 0.42007667 \\ &&\vdots & &&\vdots & \vdots \\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

In matrix notation this would be

\begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & −0.97475132 & (−0.97475132)^2 \\ 1 & −0.51516923 & (−0.51516923)^2 \\ 1 & 1.12807075 & (1.12807075)^2 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} w_0 \\ w_1 \\ w_2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.02398749 \\ 0.12831898 \\ 0.42007667\\ \vdots\\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

or \begin{equation*} Zw=y \end{equation*}

where \begin{equation*} Z=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & −0.97475132 & (−0.97475132)^2 \\ 1 & −0.51516923 & (−0.51516923)^2 \\ 1 & 1.12807075 & (1.12807075)^2 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & x & x^2 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

So all we have to do is solve $Zw=y$ for $w$.

What about higher order polynomials?
Use the same procedure:

  • Construct Z \begin{equation*} Z=\begin{bmatrix}1 & x & x^2 &\cdots& x^d \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

  • Solve \begin{equation*} Zw=y \end{equation*} for $w$.

Let's try it below for d=7

for i in range(d):
    k=i+1
    Z[:,k]=x**k;

#print(Z)
sol=np.linalg.lstsq(Z,y,rcond=None)
w=sol[0]
print(w)

yreg=Z @ w
fig, ax=plt.subplots()
ax.plot(x,y,'bo')
ax.plot(x,yreg,'r*')
ax.set_xlabel("$x$")
ax.set_ylabel("$y$")


xr=np.linspace(-2,2,1000)
yr=xr*0;
for i in range(d+1):
    yr= yr+w[i]*(xr**i)
    
ytarget=np.sin(xr**3+xr**2)
ax.plot(xr,yr,'m')

Nonlinear Transformation for the Polynomial Fitting¶

Let's switch a bit of perspective.
Let's create a transformation that takes $x$ and maps it to $[1,x,x^2,\cdots, x^d]$, \begin{equation*} z=T(x)=\begin{bmatrix}1 & x & x^2 &\cdots& x^d \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*} i.e. the new point $z$ has coordinates \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} z_0=1\; \\ z_1=x\; \\ z_2=x^2\\ \vdots \\ z_d=x^d \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

And the approximating linear function in this new space is the best function of the form \begin{equation*} h(z)=w_0z_0+w_1z_1+\cdots +w_dz_d \end{equation*}

  • Then form $Z$ by stacking the coordinates of each transformed point \begin{equation*} Z=\begin{bmatrix}z_0 & z_1 & z_2 &\cdots& z_d \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
  • Solve for $w$ \begin{equation*} Zw=y \end{equation*}

General Nonlinear Transformation¶

Given the original point $x\in\mathbb{R}^n$, (i.e., $n$ real coordinates) \begin{equation*} x=\left[x_0,x_1,\ldots,x_n \right] \end{equation*} we can use a transformation \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} T&:&\mathbb{R}^n & \rightarrow & \mathbb{R}^d\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*} to transform to a point $z\in \mathbb{R}^d$ (i.e., $d$ real coordinates),

\begin{equation*} z=T(x)=\left[z_0,z_1,\ldots,z_n \right] \end{equation*}

We now work with the transform data points
I.e.,

  • Find the best linear function
    \begin{equation*} h(z)=w_0z_0+w_1z_1+\cdots +w_dz_d \end{equation*} by solving for $w$ \begin{equation*} Zw=y \end{equation*} where $Z$ is formed stacking the coordinates of each transformed point \begin{equation*} Z=\begin{bmatrix}z_0 & z_1 & z_2 &\cdots& z_d \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

Other Dataset¶

These datasets are provided as local files that need to be loaded.

Handwritten Digits¶

The dataset used in the video lectures.
Normalized handwritten digits, automatically scanned from envelopes by the U.S. Postal Service. The original scanned digits are binary and of different sizes and orientations; the images here have been deslanted and size normalized, resulting in 16 x 16 grayscale images (Le Cun et al., 1990).

Heart Failure Dataset¶

https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Heart+failure+clinical+records

Thirteen (13) clinical features:

  • age: age of the patient (years)
  • anaemia: decrease of red blood cells or hemoglobin (boolean)
  • high blood pressure: if the patient has hypertension (boolean)
  • creatinine phosphokinase (CPK): level of the CPK enzyme in the blood (mcg/L)
  • diabetes: if the patient has diabetes (boolean)
  • ejection fraction: percentage of blood leaving the heart at each contraction (percentage)
  • platelets: platelets in the blood (kiloplatelets/mL)
  • sex: woman or man (binary)
  • serum creatinine: level of serum creatinine in the blood (mg/dL)
  • serum sodium: level of serum sodium in the blood (mEq/L)
  • smoking: if the patient smokes or not (boolean)
  • time: follow-up period (days)
  • [target] death event: if the patient deceased during the follow-up period (boolean)

HCV Dataset¶

Modified the HCV data set found at https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/HCV+data

Removed the record with missing data. Removed the first column (the patient id). Converted categories and sex into numerical values
The target attribute for classification is Category (blood donors vs. Hepatitis C (including its progress ('just' Hepatitis C, Fibrosis, Cirrhosis).

The laboratory data are the attributes 4-13.

  1. Category (diagnosis) (values: '0=Blood Donor', '0.5=suspect Blood Donor', '1=Hepatitis', '2=Fibrosis', '3=Cirrhosis')
  2. Age (in years)
  3. Sex (1=f,0=m)
  4. ALB
  5. ALP
  6. ALT
  7. AST
  8. BIL
  9. CHE
  10. CHOL
  11. CREA
  12. GGT
  13. PROT

Relevant Papers:
Lichtinghagen R et al. J Hepatol 2013; 59: 236-42 Hoffmann G et al. Using machine learning techniques to generate laboratory diagnostic pathways â€“ a case study. J Lab Precis Med 2018; 3: 58-67

Diabetes Dataset (Bangladesh hospital)¶

Modified the Diabetes data set found at https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Early+stage+diabetes+risk+prediction+dataset.

Data Set Information:
This has been collected using direct questionnaires from the patients of Sylhet Diabetes Hospital in Sylhet, Bangladesh and approved by a doctor.

Attribute Information:

  1. Age 1.20-65
  2. Sex 0. Male, 1.Female
  3. Polyuria 1.Yes, 0.No.
  4. Polydipsia 1.Yes, 0.No.
  5. sudden weight loss 1.Yes, 0.No.
  6. weakness 1.Yes, 0.No.
  7. Polyphagia 1.Yes, 0.No.
  8. Genital thrush 1.Yes, 0.No.
  9. visual blurring 1.Yes, 0.No.
  10. Itching 1.Yes, 0.No.
  11. Irritability 1.Yes, 0.No.
  12. delayed healing 1.Yes, 0.No.
  13. partial paresis 1.Yes, 0.No.
  14. muscle stiffness 1.Yes, 0.No.
  15. Alopecia 1.Yes, 0.No.
  16. Obesity 1.Yes, 0.No.
  17. Class 1.Positive, -1.Negative.

K-Nearest Neighbors and Naive Bayes Classifiers with SciKit¶

We'll run a couple of classification learning models on a few of the datasets.
We are going to use Naive Bayes classifier and Nearest Neighbors classifier.

We will first split the dataset into two sets:

  1. A training set used to train the model on
  2. A test set to check how well we learning

After we load the data, for each model we are going to perform the following steps:

  1. Build the model (i.e., set up the model type and structure)
  2. Train the model using the training data (i.e., adjust the parameters)
  3. Make predictions using the testing data
  4. Evaluate the performace of the model
In [52]:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn import (datasets, naive_bayes, neighbors, model_selection)

Iris Dataset¶

Load the dataset and split into training and testing sets¶

In [53]:
iris=datasets.load_iris()
(Xtrain_iris, Xtest_iris, Ytrain_iris, Ytest_iris)=model_selection.train_test_split(iris.data, iris.target, test_size=.3)

print("Dimensions of the training set X data : ", Xtrain_iris.shape,"\n")
print("Dimensions of the testing set X data : ", Xtest_iris.shape,"\n")

print("Feature Names :", iris.feature_names)
print("Categories : ", iris.target_names)

Dimensions of the training set X data :  (105, 4) 

Dimensions of the testing set X data :  (45, 4) 

Feature Names : ['sepal length (cm)', 'sepal width (cm)', 'petal length (cm)', 'petal width (cm)']
Categories :  ['setosa' 'versicolor' 'virginica']

K-Nearest Neighbors Classifier¶

https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/neighbors.html#neighbors

We are going to perform the following steps

  1. Build a 3-NN (three nearest neighbors) model
  2. Train the model using the training data (i.e., adjust the parameters)
  3. Make predictions using the testing data
  4. Evaluate the performace of the model
In [54]:
knn=neighbors.KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors=3)  #step 1
knn_fit=knn.fit(Xtrain_iris, Ytrain_iris)          #step 2
In [55]:
Ypred_iris_knn=knn_fit.predict(Xtest_iris)         #step 3 - get the predicted labels given the feature inputs for the test set
# step 4
print ("Actual Labels   :", Ytest_iris)
print ("Predicted Labels:", Ypred_iris_knn)
test_size=len(Ytest_iris)
knn_accuracy=100*np.sum(Ytest_iris==Ypred_iris_knn)/test_size
print("Accuracy         :", knn_accuracy, "%.")
print("Error            :", 100-knn_accuracy, "%.\n")

Actual Labels   : [0 1 0 2 2 2 2 1 1 2 2 2 2 1 2 2 1 2 0 0 2 1 2 0 1 0 2 2 1 2 2 0 0 1 0 0 2
 1 2 1 1 0 0 1 0]
Predicted Labels: [0 1 0 2 2 2 2 1 1 2 1 2 2 1 2 2 1 1 0 0 2 1 2 0 1 0 2 2 1 2 2 0 0 1 0 0 2
 1 2 1 1 0 0 1 0]
Accuracy         : 95.55555555555556 %.
Error            : 4.444444444444443 %.

  1. Build a naive bayes (gaussian) model
  2. Train the model using the training data (i.e., adjust the parameters)
  3. Make predictions using the testing data
  4. Evaluate the performace of the model

Handwritten Digits¶

The dataset used in the video lectures.
Normalized handwritten digits, automatically scanned from envelopes by the U.S. Postal Service. The original scanned digits are binary and of different sizes and orientations; the images here have been deslanted and size normalized, resulting in 16 x 16 grayscale images (Le Cun et al., 1990).

Load the dataset and split into training and testing sets¶

In [58]:
tfilename="C:\\Users\\gentib\\Documents\\Teaching\\Spring 2021\\CSCI 440 Machine Learning\\Datasets\\Handwritten Digits\\zip.train"
digit_data=np.loadtxt(tfilename) 
Y_dig=digit_data[:,0]
X_dig=digit_data[:,1:] 
print("Dimensions of the X data : ", X_dig.shape,"\n")

(Xtrain_dig, Xtest_dig, Ytrain_dig, Ytest_dig)=model_selection.train_test_split(X_dig, Y_dig, test_size=.3)

print("Dimensions of the training set X data : ", Xtrain_dig.shape,"\n")
print("Dimensions of the testing set X data  : ", Xtest_dig.shape,"\n")

Dimensions of the X data :  (7291, 256) 

Dimensions of the training set X data :  (5103, 256) 

Dimensions of the testing set X data  :  (2188, 256)

print(Output[:5])

Error Measure¶

  • It is a regression problem (not classification)
  • No error measure is give to us, other than the vague description to predict the target

  • It seems reasonable (and mathematically convenient) to use the square error measure. I.e. for a given hypothesis $h$ and any input $\mathbf{x}$ penalize by the square of how much it missed the target y \begin{equation*} e\left(h(\mathbf{x}),y\right)=\left(h(\mathbf{x})-y\right)^2 \end{equation*}

  • The in-sample error of a given hypothesis is the average of errors for all the points in the training set \begin{equation*} E_{in}(h)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\left(h(\mathbf{x}_k)-y_k\right)^2 \end{equation*} where $N$ is the size of the training set and $(x_k, y_k)$ are the points in the training set.

  • We are going to extimate the out of sample error for a given hypothesis $h$ by averaging the error over a set of new points drawn from the same distribution as the training set. We will call this set the test set. \begin{equation*} E_{out}(h)\approx\frac{1}{M}\sum_{k=1}^{M}\left(h(\mathbf{x}_k)-y_k\right)^2 \end{equation*} where $M$ is the size of the test set and $(\mathbf{x}_k, y_k)$ are the points in the test set (different points than the ones in the training set).

Picking the Hypothesis Set and the Algorithm¶

  • This requires quite a bit of thought and investigation, but for now let's pick a linear model as the hypothesis set. i.e. for any input $\mathbf{x}=\left(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_{10}\right)$, \begin{equation*} h(\mathbf{x})=w_0+w_1x_1+\cdots+w_{10}x_{10} \end{equation*} To remove any ambiguition, we will denote $h$ by $h_\mathbf{w}$ so that it is clear that each $\mathbf{w}$ produces a hypothesis.

  • The algorithm pick is automatic in this case once we picked the hypothesis set and the error measure : linear regression is the best (optimal) tool for the job.

Picking the best linear model using linear regression¶

  • Construct $\mathbf{X}$, and $\mathbf{y}$
In [72]:
X=np.ones((N, d+1))
X[:,1:]=Input
y=Output
  • Solve $\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w}=\mathbf{y}$ to get the wegiths $\mathbf{w}$ for the best hypothesis
In [73]:
sol=np.linalg.lstsq(X,y,rcond=None)
w=sol[0]
print("w : ", w)

w :  [ 151.44882069    5.71876565 -242.734522    489.04655164  348.74117513
 -877.59677683  550.08605133  150.86832586  251.69454041  717.59450286
   33.33083865]

Get the In-Sample Error¶

  • Using $\mathbf{w}$ from above, get the prediction for each point $\mathbf{x}$ \begin{equation*} g(\mathbf{x})=w_0+w_1x_1+\cdots+w_{10}x_{10} \end{equation*}

  • Using matrix notation this can be done using \begin{equation*} \mathbf{g}=\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} \end{equation*} where $ \mathbf{g}$ is the vector of all predictions

  • The error of $ \mathbf{g}$ is $\text{np.mean}(\left(\mathbf{g}-\mathbf{y}\right)^2)$
In [74]:
g = X @ w
Ein=np.mean((g-y)**2)
print(np.sqrt(Ein))

54.129740814401714

Get the Out-of-Sample Error Estimate¶

  • Using $\mathbf{w}$ from above, get the prediction for each point $\mathbf{x}$ in the test set. Let denote by $\mathbf{x_t}$ and $y_t$ the input and output of the points in the test set.

  • Using matrix notation this can be done using \begin{equation*} \mathbf{g_t}=\mathbf{X_t}\mathbf{w} \end{equation*} where $ \mathbf{g_t}$ is the vector of all predictions for the test set

  • The error of $ \mathbf{g_t}$ is $\text{np.mean}(\left(\mathbf{g_t}-\mathbf{y_t}\right)^2)$
In [75]:
[M, d]=np.shape(Xtest)
Xt=np.ones((M, d+1))
Xt[:,1:]=Xtest
yt=Ytest

gt=Xt @ w
Eout=np.mean((gt-yt)**2)
print(np.sqrt(Eout))

51.97039279773035

Note¶

You do not need to go to $\mathbb{R}^3$ to get the data to be linearly separable. Indeed we can use the following transformation \begin{equation*} \tilde{T}:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} \end{equation*} defined by \begin{equation*} z=\tilde{T}\left(x\right)=\left(x+1\right)\left(x^2-9\right) \end{equation*}

In [92]:
fig, ax=plt.subplots(1,2, figsize=(10,3))
ax[0].plot(  xa[ya>0], xa[ya>0]*0,'r+')
ax[0].plot( xa[ya<0], xa[ya<0]*0, 'bo')
ax[0].set_xlabel('$x$')
ax[0].set_title('$\mathbf{X}$-space')

z = (xa+1)*(xa**2-9);
ax[1].plot(z[ya>0], z[ya>0]*0, 'r+')
ax[1].plot(z[ya<0], z[ya<0]*0, 'bo')
ax[1].set_xlabel('$z_1$')
ax[1].set_xlabel('$z_2$')
ax[1].set_title('$\mathbf{Z}$-space')
Out[92]:
Text(0.5, 1.0, '$\\mathbf{Z}$-space')

Notice that in this $\mathbf{Z}$-space the data is linearly separable. However we cheated because we guessed the right transformation by looking at the data. We will learn later in the class why this is a bad idea.

Heart Failure Dataset

https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Heart+failure+clinical+records

Thirteen (13) clinical features:

  • age: age of the patient (years)
  • anaemia: decrease of red blood cells or hemoglobin (boolean)
  • high blood pressure: if the patient has hypertension (boolean)
  • creatinine phosphokinase (CPK): level of the CPK enzyme in the blood (mcg/L)
  • diabetes: if the patient has diabetes (boolean)
  • ejection fraction: percentage of blood leaving the heart at each contraction (percentage)
  • platelets: platelets in the blood (kiloplatelets/mL)
  • sex: woman or man (binary)
  • serum creatinine: level of serum creatinine in the blood (mg/dL)
  • serum sodium: level of serum sodium in the blood (mEq/L)
  • smoking: if the patient smokes or not (boolean)
  • time: follow-up period (days)
  • [target] death event: if the patient deceased during the follow-up period (boolean)

Training, Testing and Generalization Bounds¶

Using Naive Bayes

  1. Split the data 50/50 between training and testing
  2. Estimate $E_{out}-E_{in}$
  3. Repeat T times 1. and 2. to get a distribution of $E_{out}-E_{in}$
In [95]:
T=10000
alpha=0.5
e_in=[]
e_out=[]
for i in range(T):
    (Xtrain, Xtest, Ytrain, Ytest)=model_selection.train_test_split(X_hfd, 2*Y_hfd-1, test_size=alpha)
    nb=naive_bayes.GaussianNB()            
    nb_fit=nb.fit(Xtrain, Ytrain)           
    gtrain=nb_fit.predict(Xtrain)
    gtest=nb_fit.predict(Xtest)

    e_in.append(np.mean(gtrain!=Ytrain))
    e_out.append(np.mean(gtest!=Ytest))

e_in=np.array(e_in)
e_out=np.array(e_out)

Effect of Training Data Size on $E_{in}$ and $E_{out}$¶

aa=np.mgrid[0.9:0:-0.1]
T=10000 #number of tries for each alpha

Ein=[]
Eout=[]

sEin=[]
sEout=[]

for alpha in aa:

    e_in=[]
    e_out=[]
    for i in range(T):
        (Xtrain, Xtest, Ytrain, Ytest)=model_selection.train_test_split(X_hfd, 2*Y_hfd-1, test_size=alpha)
        nb=naive_bayes.GaussianNB()            
        nb_fit=nb.fit(Xtrain, Ytrain)           
        gtrain=nb_fit.predict(Xtrain)
        gtest=nb_fit.predict(Xtest)

        e_in.append(np.mean(gtrain!=Ytrain))
        e_out.append(np.mean(gtest!=Ytest))
    Ein.append(np.mean(e_in))
    Eout.append(np.mean(e_out))
    sEin.append(np.std(e_in))
    sEout.append(np.std(e_out))

VC Dimension¶

The VC inequality \begin{equation*} \mathbb{P}\left[ \left|E_{in}\left(g\right)-E_{out}\left(g\right)\right|>\epsilon\right]\leq 4 m_{\mathcal{H}}\left(2N\right)e^{-\frac{1}{8}\epsilon^2N} \end{equation*}

Let's define

\begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} \delta= 4 m_{\mathcal{H}}\left(2N\right)e^{-\frac{1}{8}\epsilon^2N} & \implies & \epsilon=\sqrt{\frac{8}{N}\text{ln}\frac{4 m_{\mathcal{H}}\left(2N\right)}{\delta}} \\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

and

\begin{equation*} \Omega\left(N,\mathcal{H},\delta\right)=\sqrt{\frac{8}{N}\text{ln}\frac{4 m_{\mathcal{H}}\left(2N\right)}{\delta}} \end{equation*}

Then the VC inequality transforms to:

with probability $\geq 1-\delta$, \begin{equation*} \left|E_{in}\left(g\right)-E_{out}\left(g\right)\right| \leq \Omega\left(N,\mathcal{H},\delta\right) \end{equation*}




i.e., with probability $\geq1-\delta$, \begin{equation*} E_{out} \leq E_{in} + \Omega \end{equation*}

Generalization bound $\Omega$

  1. Gets smaller for larger training set size $N$
  2. Gets larger for larger VC dimension (more complex $\mathcal{H}$)

Next we illustrate the effect of $N$ and $d_{VC}$ on the generalization bound $\Omega$ using the handwritten digits dataset.

In [101]:
import numpy as np

Handwritten Digits¶

The dataset used in the video lectures.
Normalized handwritten digits, automatically scanned from envelopes by the U.S. Postal Service. The original scanned digits are binary and of different sizes and orientations; the images here have been deslanted and size normalized, resulting in 16 x 16 grayscale images (Le Cun et al., 1990).

We are only going to use only two of the digits (to see if we can distinguish between the two of them)

Effect of $N$ on $\Omega$¶

Using the Perceptron Learning Model

One Run with a 50/50 Split (Train/Test)¶

In [103]:
alpha=0.5
(Xtrain, Xtest, Ytrain, Ytest)=model_selection.train_test_split(Input, Output, test_size=alpha)
pmodel=linear_model.Perceptron()
pmodel_fit=pmodel.fit(Xtrain, Ytrain)
gtrain=pmodel_fit.predict(Xtrain)

e_out=np.mean(gtest!=Ytest)

Effect of $d_{VC}$ on $\Omega$¶

Using the Perceptron Learning Model

  • $d_{VC}=257$ for the perceptron model used above.
  • We are going to extract two features from the data (the average pixel intensity and the symmetry) and use the perceptron in the new space. The VC dimension of the perceptron in the new space is 3.

Transform the Data to Make it 2 Dimensional

In [107]:
def fsTransform(x):
    z=np.zeros((len(x),2))
    z[:,0]=np.mean(x,1)
    z[:,1]=np.mean(x[:,:128],1)-np.mean(x[:,128:],1)
    return z

Bias Variance Decomposition¶

\begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} \textbf{bias} & = & \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\left(\bar{g}\left(x\right)-f\left(x\right)\right)^2\right]\\ \textbf{var} & = & \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\left[\left(g^{\left(\mathcal{D}\right)}\left(x\right)-\bar{g}\left(x\right)\right)^2\right]\right]\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}
In [112]:

A Simple Example¶

Let's look at the example discussed in the lectures and solve it exactly.

  • Target function: \begin{equation*} f(x)=sin(\pi x), x\in[-1,1] \end{equation*}

  • N=2 (two training points available)

  • Two hypotheses sets: \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} \mathcal{H}_0: & h(x) =b \\ \mathcal{H}_1: & h(x) =ax+b \\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

Generate a test set

#Generate training set
Ntrain=2
Xtrain=np.random.rand(Ntrain)*2-1
Ytrain=np.sin(np.pi*Xtrain)

#H0, h(x)=b0
#Get b0 using LR
X0=np.ones((Ntrain,1))
sol=np.linalg.lstsq(X0,Ytrain,rcond=None)
b0=sol[0][0]

#H1, h(x)=a1 x + b1
#Get a1,b1 using LR
X1=np.ones((Ntrain,2))
X1[:, 1]=Xtrain
sol=np.linalg.lstsq(X1,Ytrain,rcond=None)
b1, a1=sol[0]

fig, ax1=plt.subplots()
ax1.plot([-1,1],[b0,b0], 'r')
ax1.plot([-1,1],[-a1+b1,a1+b1], 'b')
ax1.plot(Xtest,Ytest,'g')
ax1.plot(Xtrain,Ytrain,'k.',  markersize=15)
ax1.legend(["g(x)=b","g(x)=ax+b", "target function", "Dataset"])

ax1.set_ylabel("y")
ax1.grid()

P=10;

for i in range(P):
    #Generate training set
    Ntrain=2
    Xtrain=np.random.rand(Ntrain)*2-1
    Ytrain=np.sin(np.pi*Xtrain)

    #H0, h(x)=b0
    #Get b0 using LR
    X0=np.ones((Ntrain,1))
    sol=np.linalg.lstsq(X0,Ytrain,rcond=None)
    b0=sol[0][0]

    #H0, h(x)=a1 x + b1
    #Get a1,b1 using LR
    X1=np.ones((Ntrain,2))
    X1[:, 1]=Xtrain
    sol=np.linalg.lstsq(X1,Ytrain,rcond=None)
    b1, a1=sol[0]
    abar=abar+a1;
    bbar=bbar+b1;
    #plot
 
    ax2[0].plot([-1,1],[b0,b0], 'r', linewidth=0.5)
    if i==0:
        ax2[0].plot(Xtest,Ytest,'g', linewidth=3)
        ax2[0].legend(["h(x)=b", "target function"])
        ax2[0].set_xlabel("x")
        ax2[0].set_ylabel("y")
    ax2[0].plot(Xtrain,Ytrain,'k.', markersize=15)

    
    ax2[1].plot([-1,1],[-a1+b1,a1+b1], 'b', linewidth=0.5)
    if i==0:
        ax2[1].plot(Xtest,Ytest,'g', linewidth=3)
        ax2[1].legend(["h(x)=ax+b", "target function"])
        ax2[1].set_xlabel("x")
        ax2[1].set_ylabel("y")
    ax2[1].plot(Xtrain,Ytrain,'k.', markersize=15)

ax2[0].axis([-1,1, -2, 2])
ax2[1].axis([-1,1, -2, 2])

Bias Variance Decomposition¶

Recall

  • Target function: \begin{equation*} f(x)=sin(\pi x), x\in[-1,1] \end{equation*}

  • N=2 (two training points available)

  • Two hypotheses sets: \begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} \mathcal{H}_0: & h(x) =b \\ \mathcal{H}_1: & h(x) =ax+b \\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}
\begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} \textbf{bias} & = & \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\left(\bar{g}\left(x\right)-f\left(x\right)\right)^2\right]\\ \textbf{var} & = & \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\left[\left(g^{\left(\mathcal{D}\right)}\left(x\right)-\bar{g}\left(x\right)\right)^2\right]\right]\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}

Here is an outline of the process
For any hypothesis set $\mathcal{H}$ and some number of iterations $T$

  1. Generate a large enough test set $\mathcal{X}_{test}$
  2. For $k$ in range($T$):
    • Generate a set $\mathcal{D}^{\left(k\right)}$ composed of 2 points
    • Pick the hypothesis $g^{\left(k\right)}$ from $\mathcal{H}$ that best fits the data $\mathcal{D}^{\left(k\right)}$
    • For all $x\in\mathcal{X}_{test}$, calculate $g^{\left(k\right)}\left(x\right)$
  3. For all $x\in\mathcal{X}_{test}$, calculate $\bar{g}\left(x\right)$ as the average over all $g^{\left(k\right)}\left(x\right)$
  4. Calculate the bias and variance using the formulas above.

Note
In general, given two points $(x_1,y_1)$ and $(x_2,y_2)$,

  • The best constant fit is given by $g(x)=b_0$ where $b_0=\frac{y_1+y_2}{2}$
  • The best linear fit is given by $g(x)=b_1+a_1x$ where $a_1=\frac{y_1-y_2}{x_1-x_2}$, $b_1=\frac{x_1y_2-x_2y_1}{x_1-x_2}$
In [116]:
#Generate N=100000 datasets of size 2
N=10000
Xtt=np.random.rand(N,2)*2-1
Ytt=np.sin(np.pi*Xtt)

#calculate b0 for each dataset
bb0=np.mean(Ytt,1)
b0bar=np.mean(bb0)

err0=0
var0=0
bias0=0
for i in range(N):
    err0=err0+np.mean(pow(Ytest-bb0[i],2))
    var0=var0+np.mean(pow(b0bar-bb0[i],2))
    bias0=bias0+np.mean(pow(b0bar-Ytest,2))
    
err0=err0/N
var0=var0/N
bias0=bias0/N
print("Hypothesis Set H0")
print("Error    : %.3f"%err0)
print("Variance : %.3f"%var0)
print("Bias     : %.3f"%bias0)

Y1=Ytt[:,0]
Y2=Ytt[:,1]
X1=Xtt[:,0]
X2=Xtt[:,1]

aa1=(Y1-Y2)/(X1-X2)
bb1=(X1*Y2-X2*Y1)/(X1-X2)


a1bar=np.mean(aa1)
b1bar=np.mean(bb1)

err1=0
var1=0
bias1=0
for i in range(N):
    h1=bb1[i]+aa1[i]*Xtest
    h1bar=b1bar+a1bar*Xtest
    err1=err1+np.mean(pow(Ytest-h1,2))
    var1=var1+np.mean(pow(h1bar-h1,2))
    bias1=bias1+np.mean(pow(h1bar-Ytest,2))
    
err1=err1/N
var1=var1/N
bias1=bias1/N
print("Hypothesis Set H1")
print("Error    : %.3f"%err1)
print("Variance : %.3f"%var1)
print("Bias     : %.3f"%bias1)

Recall

\begin{equation*} \begin{matrix} \textbf{bias} & = & \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\left(\bar{g}\left(x\right)-f\left(x\right)\right)^2\right]\\ \textbf{var} & = & \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}}\left[\left(g^{\left(\mathcal{D}\right)}\left(x\right)-\bar{g}\left(x\right)\right)^2\right]\right]\\ \end{matrix} \end{equation*}
  • To get an estimation of $\mathbb{E}_x$, we are going to preserve 20% of the data as a test set to average over
  • Assume our dataset is of about size 106, i.e., $\left|\mathcal{D}\right|=106$
  • To get an estimation of $\mathbb{E}_\mathcal{D}$, we are going to randomly generate $\mathcal{D}$ by picking 30% of the training data. Repeating the process multiple times and average.

    The approach is ok as long as the set of training data is large enough. If it is not, the estimate of $\bar{g}$ could be off by a lot. To get a better estimate we would need a much bigger training set to pick from, but we have to make due with what we have.

Here is an outline of the process
For any hypothesis set $\mathcal{H}$ and some number of iterations $T$

  1. Set aside 20% of the data. Call this set $\mathcal{X}_{test}$ and the remaining points form set $\mathcal{X}$
  2. For $k$ in range($T$):
    • Generate a set $\mathcal{D}^{\left(k\right)}$ randomly picking 30% of the points in $\mathcal{X}$
    • Pick the hypothesis $g^{\left(k\right)}$ from $\mathcal{H}$ that best fits the data $\mathcal{D}^{\left(k\right)}$
    • For all $x\in\mathcal{X}_{test}$, calculate $g^{\left(k\right)}\left(x\right)$
  3. For all $x\in\mathcal{X}_{test}$, calculate $\bar{g}\left(x\right)$ as the average over all $g^{\left(k\right)}\left(x\right)$
  4. Calculate the bias and variance using the formulas above.

Logistic Regression¶

In [1]:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from mpl_toolkits import mplot3d
from matplotlib import cm

Recall some definitions

  • Linear signal: \begin{equation*} s=\sum_{i=0}^{d}w_ix_i=\mathbf{w}^T\mathbf{x} \end{equation*}

  • Logistic regression \begin{equation*} h\left(x\right)=\theta\left(s\right) \end{equation*}

    where \begin{equation*} \theta\left(s\right)=\frac{e^s}{1+e^s} \end{equation*}

In [2]:
s=np.linspace(-5,5,100)
theta=np.exp(s)/(1+np.exp(s))

fig1, ax1=plt.subplots(1,3, figsize=(14,3))
ax1[0].plot(s,theta,'b', linewidth=3)
ax1[0].grid()
ax1[0].set_xlabel('s')
ax1[0].set_ylabel(r'$\theta$')
ax1[0].set_title('Sigmoid Function')

ax1[1].plot(s,np.log(theta),'b', linewidth=3)
ax1[1].grid()
ax1[1].set_xlabel('s')
ax1[1].set_ylabel(r'log($\theta$)')
ax1[1].set_title('Log of Sigmoid Function')

ax1[2].plot(s,-np.log(theta),'b', linewidth=3)
ax1[2].grid()
ax1[2].set_xlabel('s')
ax1[2].set_ylabel(r'-log($\theta$)')
ax1[2].set_title('Negative of Log of Sigmoid Function');

  • Given +1/-1 labeled data, $P\left(y|x\right)$ (i.e. probability of having label $y$ given input $x$) is given by \begin{equation*} P\left(y\:|\:\mathbf{x}\right) = \left\{ \begin{matrix} h(\mathbf{x}) & \text{for}& y=+1 \\ 1-h(\mathbf{x}) & \text{for}& y=-1 \\ \end{matrix} \right. \end{equation*}

    and \begin{equation*} P\left(y\:|\:\mathbf{x}\right) = \theta\left(y\:\mathbf{w}^T\mathbf{x}\right) \end{equation*}

  • The likelihood of a dataset $\mathcal{D}=\left\{\left(\mathbf{x}_1,y_1\right),\ldots,\left(\mathbf{x}_N,y_N\right)\right\}$ is given by

\begin{equation*} \prod_{n=1}^{N}P\left(y_n\:|\:\mathbf{x_n}\right)=\prod_{n=1}^{N} \theta\left(y\:\mathbf{w}^T\mathbf{x}\right) \end{equation*}
  • Maximizing the likelihood is the same as minimizing the negative ofthe log-likelihood, which is equivalet to minimizing $E_{in}$ given by \begin{equation*} E_{in}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\text{ln}\left(1+e^{-y_n\:\mathbf{w}^T\mathbf{x}_n}\right) \end{equation*} This is known as the cross entropy error.
  • Minimized using gradient descent

Logistic Regression Algorithm

  1. Initialize the weights at $t=0$ to $\mathbf{w}\left(0\right)$
  2. While not stopping criteria is not met
    • compute the gradient \begin{equation*} \nabla E_{in}=-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{y_n\:\mathbf{x}_n}{\left(1+e^{\,y_n\,\mathbf{w}^T\mathbf{x}_n}\right)} \end{equation*}
    • update the weights: \begin{equation*} \mathbf{w}\left(t+1\right)=\mathbf{w}\left(t\right)-\eta\nabla E_{in} \end{equation*}
    • t=t+1
  3. Return the final weights $\mathbf{w}$

In [5]:
def LogisticReg1D(x,y, eta=10, tol=0.01, w0=0, maxI=10):

    wt=w0
    ein=np.mean(np.log(1+np.exp(-y*(1+wt*x))))
    W=[w0]
    Ein=[ein]
 
    t=0
    deltaE=10
    while (t<maxI):
        gt=np.mean((-y*x)/(1+np.exp(y*(1+wt*x))))
        wt=wt-eta*gt
        ein=np.mean(np.log(1+np.exp(-y*(1+wt*x))))
        deltaE=np.abs(ein-Ein[t])
        W.append(wt)
        Ein.append(ein)
        t=t+1
    return [np.array(W), np.array(Ein)]

In [11]:
def LogisticReg2D(x1,x2,y, eta=10, tol=0.01, w0=[0,0], maxI=10):

    wt1=w0[0]
    wt2=w0[1]
    ein=np.mean(np.log(1+np.exp(-y*(1+wt1*x1+wt2*x2))))
    W1=[wt1]
    W2=[wt2]
    Ein=[ein]
 
    t=0
    deltaE=10
    while (t<maxI):
        gt1=np.mean((-y*x1)/(1+np.exp(y*(1+wt1*x1+wt2*x2))))
        gt2=np.mean((-y*x2)/(1+np.exp(y*(1+wt1*x1+wt2*x2))))
        wt1=wt1-eta*gt1
        wt2=wt2-eta*gt2
        ein=np.mean(np.log(1+np.exp(-y*(1+wt1*x1+wt2*x2))))
        deltaE=np.abs(ein-Ein[t])
        W1.append(wt1)
        W2.append(wt2)
        Ein.append(ein)
        t=t+1
    return [np.array(W1),np.array(W2), np.array(Ein)]

Neural Networks Using TensorFlow¶

  • We are going to use the Fashion MNIST dataset
  • Following this tutorial https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/keras/classification
In [2]:
import tensorflow as tf
from tensorflow import keras
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Load the Data Using Keras¶

  • Data is split between training and testing
In [5]:
data=keras.datasets.fashion_mnist
(trainx, trainy), (testx, testy)=data.load_data()
print("Training data dimensions : ", trainx.shape)
print("Testing data dimensions : ", testx.shape)

Nx, n2, n3 = trainx.shape

Training data dimensions :  (60000, 28, 28)
Testing data dimensions :  (10000, 28, 28)
  • Each data point is a 28x28 image
  • Each label is a value 0 to 9 corresponding to the following classes 
    0    T-shirt/top
1    Trouser
2    Pullover
3    Dress
4    Coat
5    Sandal
6    Shirt
7    Sneaker
8    Bag
9    Ankle boot
  • We normalize each image by dividing by 255 (so that each pixel is between 0 and 1, better for using in NN)
In [6]:
class_names = ['T-shirt/top', 'Trouser', 'Pullover', 'Dress', 'Coat',
               'Sandal', 'Shirt', 'Sneaker', 'Bag', 'Ankle boot']
trainxn=trainx/255.0
testxn=testx/255.0
fig, ax=plt.subplots()
ax.imshow(trainxn[0], cmap=plt.cm.binary)
ax.set_title(class_names[trainy[0]])
ax.axis('off');

Building the NN Model¶

In [7]:
model=keras.Sequential([ 
    keras.layers.Flatten(input_shape=(28,28)),
    keras.layers.Dense(100, activation="relu"),
    keras.layers.Dense(30, activation="relu"),
    keras.layers.Dense(10, activation="softmax")
])
model.compile(optimizer="adam", loss="sparse_categorical_crossentropy", metrics=["accuracy"])
In [8]:
model.fit(trainxn, trainy, epochs=10)

Train on 60000 samples

A Note about Processing the Data¶

  • We can change the format of each data point using reshape
  • From 28x28 array we can convert to a 784 feature vector (hence match the datasets we have work on before
In [22]:
n1, n2, n3 = trainx.shape
print(trainx.shape)
ddx=np.reshape(trainx, (n1, n2*n3))
print(ddx.shape)

(60000, 28, 28)
(60000, 784)
  • Here how we can separate the training set 70/30 randomly
In [23]:
s=0.3
tt=np.random.rand(n1)
dd1=ddx[tt>s,:]
dd2=ddx[tt<=s, :]
print(dd1.shape, dd2.shape)

(42143, 784) (17857, 784)

Overfitting Example : Polynomials¶

In [34]:
from scipy.special import eval_legendre
In [35]:
def evaluateRandPoly(x, coeff):
    d=len(coeff)
    y=np.zeros(len(x))
    for i in range(d):
        y=y+coeff[i]*eval_legendre(i, x)
    return y

def Pol(X, p=None):
    """
    Given the 1 dimensional input data x
    transform that data to [1, x, x^2, ..., x^p]
    """
    N=np.shape(X)[0]
    if p is None:
        k=1
    Z=np.ones((N, p+1))
    for i in range(p):
        Z[:,i+1]=np.power(X, i+1)
    return Z
  • Legendre Polynomials We are going to generate random polynomials of a given degree using Legendre polynomials as a basis
In [46]:
figl, axl=plt.subplots(1,3, figsize=(14,3))
t1=np.linspace(-1,1)
d=5
yy=np.zeros((d,len(t1)))
for i in range(d):
    yy[i,:]=eval_legendre(i,t1)
    axl[0].plot(t1, yy[i,:], label=r'$P_{}(x)$'.format(i))

    axl[0].set_title('Legendre Polynomials')
    axl[0].set_xlabel('x')
    axl[0].set_ylabel('y')
    axl[0].grid()
    axl[0].legend()
    
axl[1].plot(t1, 0.6*yy[1,:]+0.4*yy[4,:])
axl[1].set_title('60/40 mixture of $P_1$ and $P_4$')
axl[1].set_xlabel('x')
axl[1].set_ylabel('y')
axl[1].grid()

alpha=np.random.rand(d);
alpha=alpha/np.sqrt(alpha @ alpha)
zz=  alpha @ yy
axl[2].plot(t1, zz)
axl[2].set_title('Random mixture of $P_0$ through $P_4$')
axl[2].set_xlabel('x')
axl[2].set_ylabel('y')
axl[2].grid()

Effect of Noise in Overfitting¶

  • Generate a random polynomial of degree 10
  • Draw 15 points as a training set
  • Add different levels of noise
  • Learn using two models: second degree polynomials and 10th degree polynomials
In [55]:
degree=10
w=np.random.rand(degree+1)
w=w/(np.sqrt(w @ w))
lb=-0.9
ub=0.9

t=(ub-lb)*np.random.rand(200)+lb
t.sort()
yt=evaluateRandPoly(t,w)

N=15
sigma=[0, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1]
Y=np.zeros((4,N))
x=(ub-lb)*np.random.rand(N)+lb
Y[0,:]=evaluateRandPoly(x,w)

for i in range(3):
    Y[i+1,:]=Y[0,:]+np.random.normal(0,sigma[i+1],N)



fig3, ax3=plt.subplots(1,4,figsize=(18,3))
for i in range(4):
    ax3[i].plot(t,yt, 'r')
    ax3[i].plot(x,Y[i], 'ko')
    ax3[i].set_xlabel('x')
    ax3[i].set_ylabel('y')
    ax3[i].grid()
    ax3[i].axis('tight')
    ax3[i].legend(['Target d=%.0f'%degree,'Data'])
    ax3[i].set_title('$\sigma = $ %.2f'%sigma[i])
In [56]:
d1=2
Z1=Pol(x,d1)
T1=Pol(t,d1)
G1=np.zeros((4,len(t)))
for i in range(4):
    sol1=np.linalg.lstsq(Z1,Y[i,:],rcond=None)
    w1=sol1[0]
    G1[i,:]=T1 @ w1


fig4, ax4=plt.subplots(1,4,figsize=(18,3))
for i in range(4):
    ax4[i].plot(t,yt, 'r', linewidth=5)
    ax4[i].plot(x,Y[i], 'ko')
    ax4[i].axis('tight')
    ax4[i].plot(t,G1[i,:], 'b')
    ax4[i].set_xlabel('x')
    ax4[i].set_ylabel('y')
    ax4[i].grid()
    ax4[i].legend(['Target d=%.0f'%degree,'Data', 'Fit d=%.0f'%d1])
    ax4[i].set_title('$\sigma = $ %.2f'%sigma[i])
 
d2=10
Z2=Pol(x,d2)
T2=Pol(t,d2)
G2=np.zeros((4,len(t)))
for i in range(4):
    sol20=np.linalg.lstsq(Z2,Y[i,:],rcond=None)
    w20=sol20[0]
    G2[i,:]=T2 @ w20


fig5, ax5=plt.subplots(1,4,figsize=(18,3))
for i in range(4):
    ax5[i].plot(t,yt, 'r', linewidth=5)
    ax5[i].plot(x,Y[i], 'ko')
    ax5[i].axis('tight')
    ax5[i].plot(t,G2[i,:], 'b')
    ax5[i].set_xlabel('x')
    ax5[i].set_ylabel('y')
    ax5[i].grid()
    ax5[i].legend(['Target d=%.0f'%degree,'Data', 'Fit d=%.0f'%d2])
    ax5[i].set_title('$\sigma = $ %.2f'%sigma[i])

Effect of Target Complexity in Overfitting¶

  • Generate a random polynomials of various degrees
  • Draw 15 points as a training set
  • Learn using two models: second degree polynomials and 10th degree polynomials
In [57]:
degs=[10, 15,25,40,50]
K=len(degs)
fig6, ax6=plt.subplots(1,K,figsize=(4*K+2,3))
fig7, ax7=plt.subplots(1,K,figsize=(4*K+2,3))

for i in range(K):
    
    degree=degs[i]
    w=np.random.rand(degree+1)
    w=w/(np.sqrt(w @ w))
    lb=-0.9
    ub=0.9

    t=(ub-lb)*np.random.rand(200)+lb
    t.sort()
    yt=evaluateRandPoly(t,w)

    N=15
    x=(ub-lb)*np.random.rand(N)+lb
    YY=evaluateRandPoly(x,w)

    
    d1=2
    Z1=Pol(x,d1)
    T1=Pol(t,d1)
    sol1=np.linalg.lstsq(Z1,YY,rcond=None)
    w1=sol1[0]
    G1=T1 @ w1


    ax6[i].plot(t,yt, 'r', linewidth=5)
    ax6[i].plot(x,YY, 'ko')
    ax6[i].axis('tight')
    ax6[i].plot(t,G1, 'b')
    ax6[i].set_xlabel('x')
    ax6[i].set_ylabel('y')
    ax6[i].grid()
    ax6[i].legend(['Target d=%.0f'%degree,'Data', 'Fit d=%.0f'%d1])
    ax6[i].set_title('Polynomial of Degree %.0f'%degree)
    
    d2=10
    Z2=Pol(x,d2)
    T2=Pol(t,d2)
    
    sol20=np.linalg.lstsq(Z2,YY,rcond=None)
    w20=sol20[0]
    G2=T2 @ w20


    ax7[i].plot(t,yt, 'r', linewidth=5)
    ax7[i].plot(x,YY, 'ko')
    ax7[i].axis('tight')
    ax7[i].plot(t,G2, 'b')
    ax7[i].set_xlabel('x')
    ax7[i].set_ylabel('y')
    ax7[i].grid()
    ax7[i].legend(['Target d=%.0f'%degree,'Data', 'Fit d=%.0f'%d2])
    ax7[i].set_title('Polynomial of Degree %.0f'%degree)

from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
scaler = StandardScaler() 
scaler.fit(Xtrain)
XtrainS = scaler.transform(Xtrain) 
XtestS = scaler.transform(Xtest)

  • Using a network with 1 hidden layer of 10 perceptrons

    ~320 parameters (30 inputs x 10 hidden perceptrons x 1 output perceptron + biases)

  • Batch gradient descent with regularization parameter alpha2 in a range of values

    take the results with a grain of salt. The split of the data provides a lot of randomness

In [42]:
alpha2=[0, 0.1, 0.5, 1, 10, 100]
AK=len(alpha2)
fig, ax=plt.subplots(1, AK, figsize=(3*AK+2,3))
Nx=len(XtrainS)
    
for j in range(AK):
    reg_alpha=alpha2[j]


    nn1 = neural_network.MLPClassifier(solver='adam', hidden_layer_sizes=(10 ), activation='tanh', alpha=reg_alpha,
                                           learning_rate_init=0.1, max_iter=500, tol=1e-6, verbose=False, batch_size=Nx)


    K=200
    classes=np.unique(Ytrain)
    Ein=[]
    Eout=[]
    for i in range(K):
        nn1.partial_fit(XtrainS, Ytrain, classes)
        Ein.append(100*(1-nn1.score(XtrainS, Ytrain)))
        Eout.append(100*(1-nn1.score(XtestS, Ytest)))
        
    ax[j].plot(Ein,'-b')
    ax[j].plot(Eout,'-r')
    ax[j].set_xlabel('Epoch #')
    ax[j].set_ylabel('Error')
    ax[j].set_title('$\lambda$=%.3f'%reg_alpha)
    ax[j].grid()
    ax[j].legend(['E_in', 'E_out'])
    ax[j].axis([0,200,0,10])

Regularization Example : Polynomials¶

https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/linear_model.html#ridge-regression-and-classification

  • Using Ridge regression (L2 regularization). There are better regularizers, but just illustrating the point.
  • A bit different from what I showed in class. I will be using the Lengrendre polynomials for the nonlinear transformation
In [43]:
from scipy.special import eval_legendre
def evaluateRandPoly(x, coeff):
    d=len(coeff)
    y=np.zeros(len(x))
    for i in range(d):
        y=y+coeff[i]*eval_legendre(i, x)
    return y

def LPol(X, p=None):
    """
    Given the 1 dimensional input data x
    transform that data to [1, x, x^2, ..., x^p]
    """
    N=np.shape(X)[0]
    if p is None:
        k=1
    Z=np.ones((N, p+1))
    for i in range(p):
        Z[:,i+1]=eval_legendre(i+1, X)
    return Z

    d2=10
    Z2=LPol(x,d2)
    T2=LPol(t,d2)
    G2=np.zeros((4,len(t)))
    for i in range(4):
        reg = linear_model.Ridge(alpha=lam, fit_intercept=False)
        reg.fit(Z2, Y[i,:])
        w20=reg.coef_
        G2[i,:]=T2 @ w20



    for i in range(4):
        ax5[k][i].plot(t,yt, 'r', linewidth=5)
        ax5[k][i].plot(x,Y[i], 'ko')
        ax5[k][i].axis('tight')
        ax5[k][i].plot(t,G2[i,:], 'b')
        if (k==KK-1):
            ax5[k][i].set_xlabel('x')
        if (i==0): 
            ax5[k][i].set_ylabel('$\lambda$=%1.4f'%lam)
        ax5[k][i].grid()
        ax5[k][i].legend(['Target d=%.0f'%degree,'Data', 'Fit'])
        if (k==0):
            ax5[k][i].set_title('$\sigma = $ %.2f'%sigma[i])

High Order Polynomial Data¶

In [50]:
rg_lambda=[0, 0.001, 0.01, 0.1, 1, 10]
degs=[10,25,40,50, 100]
K=len(degs)
KK=len(rg_lambda)
fig7, ax7=plt.subplots(KK,K,figsize=(3*K+2,3*KK+1))
Err=np.zeros((KK, K))
for i in range(K):
    degree=degs[i]
    w=np.random.rand(degree+1)
    w=w/(np.sqrt(w @ w))
    lb=-0.9
    ub=0.9

    t=(ub-lb)*np.random.rand(200)+lb
    t.sort()
    yt=evaluateRandPoly(t,w)

    N=15
    x=(ub-lb)*np.random.rand(N)+lb
    YY=evaluateRandPoly(x,w)

    d2=10
    Z2=LPol(x,d2)
    T2=LPol(t,d2)
   
    for j in range(KK):
        lam=rg_lambda[j]
  
        regc = linear_model.Ridge(alpha=lam, fit_intercept=False)
        regc.fit(Z2, YY)
        w20c=regc.coef_
        G2=T2 @ w20c

        Err[j,i]=np.mean((yt-G2)**2)
        ax7[j][i].plot(t,yt, 'r', linewidth=5)
        ax7[j][i].plot(x,YY, 'ko')
        ax7[j][i].axis('tight')
        ax7[j][i].plot(t,G2, 'b')
        if (j==KK-1):
            ax7[j][i].set_xlabel('x')
        if (i==0): 
            ax7[j][i].set_ylabel('$\lambda$=%1.4f'%lam)
        ax7[j][i].grid()
        ax7[j][i].legend(['Target','Data', 'Fit'])
        if (j==0):
            ax7[j][i].set_title('Polynomial of Degree %.0f'%degree)

Splitting the Data for Cross Validation¶

10 fold cross validation

In [30]:
tt=np.random.permutation(N) #generate a random permutation
m=N/10 #the size of the validation set
figc, axc=plt.subplots(1,10,figsize=(50,4))
for k in range(10):  
    lb=k*m  
    ub=(k+1)*m 
    #lb and ub establish a range for the indexes to be included in the validation set
    #e.g. N=100, m=10
    # k=0 ->   lb=0, ub=10
    # k=1 ->   lb=10, ub=20 etc.
    
    
    valind=(tt<ub) & (tt>=lb) #indexes of the points in the validation set (true if it falls in the range)
    trainind=~(valind) #indexes of the points in the training set
 
    Xval=X[valind, :]
    Yval=Y[valind]  #the validation set
    Xtrain=X[trainind, :]
    Ytrain=Y[trainind]  #the training set (both depend on k, so will get 10 different ones)
    
    #now we have a 9:1 split of the data into train and validation sets
    #for each k, we get a different split
    
    #let's try doing smth, like plotting
    
    axc[k].plot(Xtrain[Ytrain>0,0],Xtrain[Ytrain>0,1],'r+')
    axc[k].plot(Xtrain[Ytrain<0,0],Xtrain[Ytrain<0,1],'bo')
    axc[k].plot(Xval[Yval>0,0],Xval[Yval>0,1],'k+')
    axc[k].plot(Xval[Yval<0,0],Xval[Yval<0,1],'ko')
    #black are the point in the validation set
    axc[k].set_xlabel("$x_1$")
    if k==0:
        axc[k].set_ylabel("$x_2$")

In [33]:
fig3, ax3=plt.subplots(1,10,figsize=(50,4))

err=[]
nv=[]
for k in range(10):  
    lb=k*m  
    ub=(k+1)*m 
    #lb and ub establish a range for the indexes to be included in the validation set
    #e.g. N=400, m=40
    # k=0 ->   lb=0, ub=40
    # k=1 ->   lb=40, ub=80 etc.
    
    
    valind=(tt<ub) & (tt>=lb) #indexes of the points in the validation set (true if it falls in the range)
    trainind=~(valind) #indexes of the points in the training set
 
    Xval=X[valind, :]
    Yval=Y[valind]  #the validation set
    Xtrain=X[trainind, :]
    Ytrain=Y[trainind]  #the training set (both depend on k, so will get 10 different ones)
    clf=svm.SVC(kernel='linear', C=10e6)
    clf.fit(Xtrain, Ytrain)
    g=clf.predict(Xval)
    sv=clf.support_vectors_
    err.append(np.sum(g!=Yval))
    nv.append(np.sum(clf.n_support_))
    
    t=np.linspace(-2,2)
    ww=[clf.intercept_, clf.coef_[0][0], clf.coef_[0][1]]
    y_svm=-(ww[1]*t+ww[0])/ww[2]
    yt=-(w[1]*t+w[0])/w[2]
    
    ax3[k].plot(t,y_svm,'k', label='svm')
    ax3[k].plot(t,yt,'g', label='target')
    ax3[k].plot(sv[:,0], sv[:,1], 'kx', label="Support Vectors", markersize=10)
    if k==0:
        ax3[k].legend()
    ax3[k].plot(Xtrain[Ytrain>0,0],Xtrain[Ytrain>0,1],'r+')
    ax3[k].plot(Xtrain[Ytrain<0,0],Xtrain[Ytrain<0,1],'bo')
    ax3[k].plot(Xval[g>0,0],Xval[g>0,1],'m+')
    ax3[k].plot(Xval[g<0,0],Xval[g<0,1],'go')
    ax3[k].set_xlabel("$x_1$")
    if k==0:
        ax3[k].set_ylabel("$x_2$")
    ax3[k].axis([-2.1, 2.1,-2.1, 2.1])

Notes on Unsupervised Learning¶

In [11]:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Let's generate some data¶

In [12]:
N=200
K=4
centers=np.random.rand(K,2)*15
X=np.random.normal(0,1,(N,2))
labels=np.random.randint(K, size=N)
for i in range(K):
    X[labels==i, :]-=centers[i,:]
   

fig, ax=plt.subplots(1,2, figsize=(10,4))
ax[0].plot(X[:,0], X[:,1], 'ko')
ax[0].set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax[0].set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax[0].set_title("%.0f Random Clusters"%K)


colors=['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow', 'magenta', 'brown']
for j in range(K):
    ax[1].plot(X[labels==j,0], X[labels==j,1], 'o', color=colors[j], label=str(j))
ax[1].set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax[1].set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax[1].set_title("%.0f Random Clusters"%K)
ax[1].legend()

Lloyd's Algorithm¶

In [21]:
#Step -0 Pick K random centers
ri=np.random.randint(N,size=K)
S=np.zeros((K,2))
for i in range(K):
    S[i,:]=X[ri[i],:]

fig, ax=plt.subplots(1,2, figsize=(12,5))
ax[0].plot(X[:,0], X[:,1], 'ko')
ax[0].set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax[0].set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax[0].set_title("%.0f Random Clusters"%K)

colors=['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow', 'magenta', 'brown']
for j in range(K):
    ax[1].plot(S[j,0],S[j,1], 'o', color=colors[j], label=str(j),markersize=7 )

ax[1].plot(X[:,0], X[:,1], 'k.')
ax[1].set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax[1].set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax[1].set_title("%.0f Random Clusters"%K)
ax[1].legend()
Out[21]:
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x1b898466408>
In [22]:
# step 1 - update the cluster memberships
newlabels=np.zeros(N)
for i in range(N):
    newlabels[i]=np.argmin(np.sum((S-X[i,:])**2,1))

    
fig, ax=plt.subplots(1,2, figsize=(12,5))
colors=['red', 'green', 'blue', 'yellow', 'magenta', 'brown']
for j in range(K):
    ax[0].plot(S[j,0],S[j,1], 'o', color=colors[j], label=str(j),markersize=7 )

ax[0].plot(X[:,0], X[:,1], 'k.')
ax[0].set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax[0].set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax[0].set_title("%.0f Random Clusters"%K)
ax[0].legend()

for j in range(K):
    ax[1].plot(X[newlabels==j,0], X[newlabels==j,1], '.', color=colors[j])
    ax[1].plot(S[j,0],S[j,1], 'o', color='black',markersize=7,label="PC "+str(j) )
ax[1].set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax[1].set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax[1].set_title("%.0f Random Clusters"%K)


# step 2 - update the cluster means
for j in range(K):
    S[j,:]=np.mean(X[newlabels==j, :],0)
    ax[1].plot(S[j,0],S[j,1], 'x', color='black',markersize=7,label="NC "+str(j) )
ax[1].legend()
Out[22]:
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x1b8985a7c08>

Run the code in cell above until it converges

ax2.plot(tt,Ytt,'g',label="target", linewidth=4)
ax2.set_xlabel("$x_1$")
ax2.set_ylabel("$x_2$")
ax2.legend()
Out[27]:
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x1b898843048>
In [28]:
Eout=np.mean(Ytest!=gtest)

print("SV  estimate : %.1f"%(np.sum(clf.n_support_)*100/(N-1)), "%")

Eout         : 2.2 %
SV  estimate : 4.5 %

Input Processing¶

In [1]:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy import linalg

Generate Some Toy Data¶

In [2]:
sig1=2
mu1=4
sig2=0.5
mu2=-2
N=200
x1o=np.random.normal(mu1,sig1, size=N)
x2o=np.random.normal(mu2,sig2, size=N)
alpha=0.3
x1=x1o
x2=(1-alpha)*x1o+alpha*x2o

X=np.array([x1,x2]).T
print(X.shape)
fig, ax=plt.subplots(figsize=(4,4))
ax.plot(X[:,0],X[:,1], '.', color='blue')
ax.set_xlabel('$x_1$')
ax.set_ylabel('$x_2$')
ax.grid()
ax.set_title('raw input')

(200, 2)

In [17]:
sst=np.cumsum(D**2)
kk=np.array(range(len(sst)))+1
ss=(1-sst/sst[-1])*100
fig, ax=plt.subplots(figsize=(10,10))
ax.plot(kk, ss)
ax.grid()
ax.set_xlabel('k')
ax.set_ylabel('Error')
ax.set_title('Recovery error')
Out[17]:
Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Recovery error')

Note

I use the rows of V not the columns to get it to work.

Zr=Z[Y!=1,:]
